revision.text:
{{Infobox language | name = Goguryeo | nativename = Koguryo | states = [[Goguryeo]] | region = [[Manchuria]], [[Korea]] | extinct = 7th–10th century? | familycolor = altaic | fam1 = [[Koreanic languages|Koreanic]] | dia1 = [[Buyeo language|Buyeo]]? | iso3 = zkg | linglist = zkg | map = History of Korea-476.PNG | mapcaption = Goguryeo at its height in 476 {{sc|ce}}. | glotto = kogu1234 | glottorefname = Koguryo }} The '''Goguryeo language''' was a [[Koreanic languages|Koreanic language]] spoken in the ancient kingdom of [[Goguryeo]] (37 {{sc|bce}} – 668 {{sc|ce}}), one of the [[Three Kingdoms of Korea]].{{cite book|last1=Bellwood|first1=Peter|title=The Global Prehistory of Human Migration|date=2013|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|location=Malden|isbn=9781118970591}}{{cite journal|last1=Vovin|first1=Alexander|title=From Koguryo to Tamna: Slowly riding to the South with speakers of Proto-Korean|journal=Korean Linguistics|date=2013|volume=15|issue=2|pages=222-240}}{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Ki-Moon|last2=Ramsey|first2=S. Robert|title=A History of the Korean language|date=2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-66189-8}}{{cite journal|last1=Whitman|first1=John|title=Northeast Asian Linguistic Ecology and the Advent of Rice Agriculture in Korea and Japan|journal=Rice|date=2011|volume=4|issue=3-4|pages=149–158|doi=10.1007/s12284-011-9080-0}}{{cite book|last1=Unger|first1=J. Marshall|title=The role of contact in the origins of the Japanese and Korean languages|date=2009|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-8248-3279-7}} The language is also known as Old Koguryo, Koguryoic, and Koguryoan. It is unknown except for a small number of words, which mostly suggest that it was similar but not identical to the language of [[Silla language|Silla]]. Striking similarities between later [[Baekje language|Baekje]] and Goguryeo can also be found, which is consistent with the legends that describe Baekje being founded by the sons of Goguryeo's founder. The Goguryeo names for government posts are mostly similar to those of [[Baekje]] and [[Silla]].{{cn|date=July 2017}} In Samguk Sagi and Samguk Yusa, the historical books of Korea's Goryeo period, it is described that the Silla of the late Three Kingdoms is related to the language of Goguryeo and Baekje. Chinese records suggest that the languages of Goguryeo, [[Buyeo language|Buyeo]], [[Okjeo|Eastern Okjeo]], [[Dongye]], [[Baekje language|Baekje]] and [[Silla language|Silla]] were similar, while the Tungusic languages of [[Mohe people|Mohe]] and [[Yilou]] differed significantly.Fan Ye, ''[[Book of the Later Han]]'', volume 85; the ''[[:zh:s:後漢書/卷85|Dongyi Liezhuan]]''Wei Shou, ''[[Book of Wei]]'', volume 100; the ''Liezhuan'' 88, [[:zh:s:魏書/卷100|the Wuji]]Li Dashi, ''[[History of Northern Dynasties]]'', volume 94; the ''Liezhuan'' 82, [[:zh:s:北史/卷094|the Wuji]] [[Records of the Three Kingdoms|三國志]] 魏書 高句麗 : 東夷舊語以爲夫餘別種 言語諸事 多與夫餘同
(''[[Records of the Three Kingdoms]]'' : Goguryeo is a branch of Buyeo so the language is largely same to Buyeo.) [[Book of Liang|梁書]] 列傳 高驪 : 言語諸事, 多與夫餘同, 其性氣衣服有異
(''[[Book of Liang]]'' : Goguryeo language is largely same to Buyeo but there are differences in their clothings.) [[Book of Liang|梁書]] 列傳 百濟 : 今言語服章略與高驪同, 行不張拱, 拜不申足則異
(''[[Book of Liang]]'' : Baekje language is roughly same to Goguryeo.) [[Book of Liang|梁書]] 列傳 新羅 : 語言待百濟而後通焉
(''[[Book of Liang]]'' : Silla language has to be translated by Baekje so that they can communicate with China.)
(Note : a Silla delegation in China didn't have an interpreter, so a Baekje delegation assisted Silla.) [[Records of the Three Kingdoms|三國志]] 魏書 勿吉國 : 勿吉國在高句麗北, 一曰靺鞨 言語獨異
(''[[Records of the Three Kingdoms]]'' : Mohe language alone is different from Goguryeo.) [[Book of the Later Han|後漢書]] 挹婁 : 人形似夫餘, 而言語各異
(''[[Book of the Later Han]]'' : Physical appearance of Yilou people resembles Buyeo people, but their languages are different from each other.) Many experts today, including Ki-moon Lee, S. Robert Ramsey, Alexander Vovin, John Whitman and Marshall Unger, believe that Goguryeo language was a member of the Koreanic language family that either spread from southern Manchuria and the Korean peninsula at earlier times or expanded from Goguryeo during the [[Three Kingdoms of Korea]] period to Baekje and Silla by Goguryeo migrants.{{cite journal|last1=Vovin|first1=Alexander|title=From Koguryo to Tamna: Slowly riding to the South with speakers of Proto-Korean|journal=Korean Linguistics|date=2013|volume=15|issue=2|pages=222-240}}{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Ki-Moon|last2=Ramsey|first2=S. Robert|title=A History of the Korean language|date=2011|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-66189-8}}{{cite journal|last1=Whitman|first1=John|title=Northeast Asian Linguistic Ecology and the Advent of Rice Agriculture in Korea and Japan|journal=Rice|date=2011|volume=4|issue=3-4|pages=149–158|doi=10.1007/s12284-011-9080-0}}{{cite book|last1=Unger|first1=J. Marshall|title=The role of contact in the origins of the Japanese and Korean languages|date=2009|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-8248-3279-7}} It is argued that the connections of Goguryeo toponyms to Japonic may be due to earlier languages of southern Korea prior to the expansion of Koreanic languages.Toh Soo Hee, [http://www.historyfoundation.or.kr/Data/DataGarden/Journal(02-2)(2).pdf About Early Paekche Language Mistaken as Being Koguryo Language] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226195328/http://www.historyfoundation.or.kr/Data/DataGarden/Journal%2802-2%29%282%29.pdf |date=2009-02-26 }}, Ch'ungnam University Words of Goguryeo origin can be found in [[Middle Korean]] (early 10th to late 14th century). [[Alexander Vovin]] (2017){{Cite journal|last=Vovin|first=Alexander|date=June 2017|title=Koreanic loanwords in Khitan and their importance in the decipherment of the latter|url=https://akademiai.com/doi/abs/10.1556/062.2017.70.2.4|journal=Acta Orientalia Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae|language=en|volume=70|issue=2|pages=207–215|doi=10.1556/062.2017.70.2.4|issn=0001-6446}} notes that the [[Khitan language]] has many [[Koreanic languages|Koreanic]] loanwords that are not found in the Mongolian and Tungusic languages, which are presumably derived from the Goguryeo language. [[Christopher I. Beckwith]] links [[Buyeo languages|Buyeo]], Goguryeo, and [[Baekje language|Baekje]] with [[Japonic languages]].{{cite journal|last1=Beckwith|first1=Christopher|title=The Ethnolinguistic History of the Early Korean Peninsula Region: Japanese-Koguryic and other Languages in the Koguryo, Paekche, and Silla kingdoms|journal=Journal of Inner and East Asian Studies|date=2005|volume=2-2|pages=33-64}} This work was criticized for serious methodological flaws, such as rejecting mainstream reconstruction of Chinese and Japanese and using his own instead.{{cite journal|last1=Pellard|first1=Thomas|title=Koguryo, the Language of Japan's Continental Relatives: An Introduction to the Historical-Comparative Study of the Japanese-Kgouryoic Languages with a Preliminary Description of Archaic Northeastern Middle Chinese (review)|journal=Korean Studies|date=2005|volume=29|pages=167–170|doi=10.1353/ks.2006.0008|url=http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/19/41/11/PDF/review-Beckwith-Koguryo.pdf}} [[Juha Janhunen]] argues that it is possible Goguryeo language could have been an Amuric language related to today's [[Nivkh language]] isolate. [https://books.google.com/books?id=LbmP_1KIQ_8C&pg=PA109 Pozzi & Janhunen & Weiers 2006], p. 109{{cite journal|last1=Janhunen|first1=Juha|title=The Lost Languages of Koguryo|journal=Journal of Inner and East Asian Studies|date=2005|volume=2-2|pages=65-86}} Comparative linguist Kang Gil-un also has argued that modern Korean is related to the [[Nivkh language]].{{cite book|last=Kang|first=Gil-un|script-title=ko:고대사의 비교언어학적 연구|year=1990|publisher=새문사}} == See also == * [[North South States Period#Language|Balhae language]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[History of the Korean language]] * [[Buyeo languages]] * [[Old Korean]] ** [[Baekje language]] ** [[Silla language]] * [[Koreanic languages]] * [[Korean influence on Japanese culture]] == References == === Citations === {{Reflist|30em}} === Bibliography === * {{cite book |title=Tumen Jalafun Jecen Aku: Manchu Studies in Honour of Giovanni Stary |editor1-first=Alessandra |editor1-last=Pozzi |editor2-first=Juha Antero|editor2-last=Janhunen |editor3-first=Michael |editor3-last=Weiers |others=Giovanni Stary |volume=Volume 20 of Tunguso Sibirica|year=2006|publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|isbn=344705378X |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LbmP_1KIQ_8C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=1 April 2013| ref = {{harvid|Otto Harrassowitz Verlag|2006}} }} ==Further reading== *Beckwith, C. I. (2004). ''Koguryo, the language of Japan's continental relatives: an introduction to the historical-comparative study of the Japanese Koguryoic languages with a preliminary description of Archaic northeastern Middle Chinese''. Brill's Japanese studies library, v. 21. Boston: Brill. {{ISBN|90-04-13949-4}} *Beckwith (2006). "Methodological Observations on Some Recent Studies of the Early Ethnolinguistic History of Korea and Vicinity." ''Altai Hakpo'' 2006, 16: 199-234. *Beckwith (2006). "The Ethnolinguistic History of the Early Korean Peninsula Region: Japanese-Koguryoic and Other Languages in the Koguryo, Paekche, and Silla Kingdoms." ''Journal of Inner and East Asian Studies'', 2006, Vol. 2-2: 34-64. *Beckwith (2007): ''Koguryo, the Language of Japan's Continental Relatives: An Introduction to the Historical-Comparative Study of the Japanese-Koguryoic Languages, with a Preliminary Description of Archaic Northeastern Middle Chinese.'' Brill Academic Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|90-04-13949-4}}. Second edition, 2007. {{ISBN|90-04-16025-6}} * http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/19/41/11/PDF/review-Beckwith-Koguryo.pdf * Alexander Vovin (2005). "[https://web.archive.org/web/20090226195328/http://www.historyfoundation.or.kr/Data/DataGarden/Journal%2802-2%29%282%29.pdf Koguryǒ and Paekche: Different Languages or Dialects of Old Korean?]" Journal of Inner and East Asian Studies, 2005, Vol. 2-2: 108-140. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goguryeo Language}} [[Category:Goguryeo]] [[Category:Extinct languages of Asia]] [[Category:History of the Korean language]] [[Category:Languages of Korea]] [[Category:Buyeo languages]] [[Category:Languages of Russia]] [[Category:Languages of China]] [[Category:Unclassified languages of Asia]]

{{globalize/US|date=December 2010}} [[Image:G grill 1869.jpg|right|250px|thumb|"G" grill on a stamp of the 1869 issue]] A '''grill''' on a [[postage stamp]] is an embossed pattern of small indentations intended to discourage [[postage stamp reuse]]. They were supposed to work by allowing the ink of the [[Cancellation (mail)|cancellation]] to be absorbed more readily by the fibres of the [[postage stamp paper|stamp paper]], making it harder to wash off the cancellation.Bennett, Russell and Watson, James; ''Philatelic Terms Illustrated'', Stanley Gibbons Publications, London (1978). == In the United States == The best-known (indeed only major) examples of grilling are the [[United States]] issues of the late 1860s and early 1870s, when grilling was standard for all US stamps. "Grilling" therefore remains a specialist interest only for American philatalists. While many types of grilled stamps are common, certain of the grill patterns were little-used, and define some of the great rarities of philately. In particular, the 1-cent stamp with the "Z" grill is generally cited as the rarest of all US stamps (only two copies are known), and is commonly known simply as the [[Z Grill]]. A recently discovered grill issue, the 30-cent "I" grill stamp, may be even rarer, for only one example has thus far been identified.{{cite web|url=http://www.siegelauctions.com/2011/1014/1014.pdf|title=Newly Discovered I Grill Rarities (pp. 80-81)|publisher=siegelauctions.com|accessdate=2014-05-04}} The idea of grilling was first suggested by [[Charles F. Steel]], a supervisor at the [[National Bank Note Company]], with correspondence on the subject dating from 1865. The purpose of grilling stamps was to break the paper fiber of the stamp. This would cause the ink cancellation mark to soak into the paper fiber making them more difficult to wash and reuse as postage.{{cn|date=February 2017}} The first type of grill to be tried, termed by philatelists the "A" grill, was applied to the entire stamp. Stamps so treated were distributed to post offices for testing in August 1867, and apparently satisfactory, as National received a contract stipulating use of grilling for all stamps. However, the actual practice of grilling on a large scale had not been completely worked out, and the process significantly weakened sheets, resulting in tearing during perforation and general production handling. National soon switched to the use of a small rectangular pattern of indentations, and subsequent grills were all of this form.Lester G. Brookman, ''The United States Postage Stamps of the Nineteenth Century, Volume II, 1861–1882'' (David G. Phillips Publishing Company, North Miami, 1989), a: pp. 67ff.; b: pp.128-131 National's contract did not specify the type of grill pattern, and the details changed as they experimented with equipment. Many of the details have been lost to history; in 1910s, philatelist [[William L. Stevenson]] introduced a system of distinguishing types of grills, and identifying them by letter. Later research clarified some of the details of chronology. No G, H, I or J grills are found on the 1861-68 issue, for this series went out of production before they were introduced. The 1869 issue used only the G grill, while the 1870 issue used H and I grills. Fears of reuse had abated by the early 1870s, and grilling seems to have been quietly dropped from the production process. Some stamps of the [[Continental Bank Note Company]] (who took over production from National) are known to have been impressed with the "J" grill as late as 1875. [[Image:Stamp US 1867 3c F grill.jpg|right|thumb|The F grill on this 1867 stamp is visible as a grid pattern in the ink of the cancellation.]] Grills: * A Grill - overall (first experimental grill) * C Grill - points up, 16-17 x 18-21 points (second experimental) * Z Grill - points down, points with horizontal ridges, 13-14 x 17-18 points * D Grill - points down, vertical ridges, 15 x 17-18 points * E Grill - points down, vertical or "X" ridges, 14 x 15-17 points * F Grill - points down, vertical or "X" ridges, 11-12 x 15-17 points * B Grill - points up, "X" ridges, 22 x 18 points * G Grill - points down, vertical ridges, 12 x 11-11.5 points * H Grill - points down, vertical ridges, 11-13 x 14-16 points * I Grill - points down, vertical ridges, 10-11 x 10-13 points * J Grill - points down, vertical ridges, 9-10 x 12 points{{cite web|url=http://www.1847us.com/Grills.htm |title=Grills on U.S. Stamps |publisher=1847us.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-04}} The least-widely used of these patterns (all associated with the 1861-68 issue) were the "B" and "C" Grills (both found on only the three-cent denomination), the "D" Grill (found only on the two-cent and three-cent denomination) and the "A" Grill (found only on the three-cent, five-cent and thirty-cent denominations). The rarest grilled U. S. stamps are: * thirty-cent I Grill (1 surviving copy—see note below) * one-cent Z Grill (2 surviving copies) * fifteen-cent Z Grill (2 surviving copies) * twelve-cent I Grill (2 surviving copies—see note below) * ninety-cent I Grill (3 surviving copies—see note below) * three-cent B Grill (4 surviving copies) * five-cent A Grill (4 surviving copies) * ten-cent Z Grill (6 surviving copies) * thirty-cent A Grill (8 surviving copies) Note: Given that intensive studies of the I Grill began only recently, additional copies of the I Grill issues listed here may well be discovered in the future. Because certain grill patterns were only belatedly recognized as features of separate collectible stamp issues, not every U. S. grilled stamp was assigned its own individual numeral in the standard Scott catalogue. Issues that share numerals are as follows:
3-cent D grill, 85; the six Z grill issues, 85A-85F.
H grill issues, 134-144; I grill issues, 134A-141A; 143A-144A.
Scott moreover lists stamps bearing the experimental J grill as minor variants (denoted by small letters) of non-grilled issues: 156e, 157c, 158e, 159b, 160a, 161c, 162a, 163a, 165c, 179c. {{Cite book |last=Snee |first=Charles (editor) |title=Scott Specialized Catalogue of United States Stamps and Covers 2013 |publisher=Scott Publishing Co |year=2012 |location= |pages=28, 38-39, 42-43 |OCLC=781677423 |isbn=0894874756 }} == The B grill == {{unreferenced section|date=April 2014}} Four stamps featuring the "B grill" pattern are known to exist, all used. All of them are of the three-cent denomination, and are numbered as Scott #82. All four stamps came from a letter sent to Prussia. The stamps were originally given a [[Mason, Texas]] cancel. Once they went to Germany (on or about March 3, 1869), they were given a German transit-date stamp. The cover was discovered in 1969 and raised controversy in the philatelic market because certain issues of the much more common "C grill" had been partially erased. This occurred during the grill roller's changing to use C grills instead of the all-over A grill. No additional "B grill" stamps have been discovered since, and one of the stamps from the cover was sold in 1993 for $85,000. Another B grill was sold again as part of the 1998 Zoellner sale (which featured the 1c Z grill) but sold for about $155,000. In 2008, the stamp was sold again, this time for over one million dollars. == In Peru == {{unreferenced section|date=April 2014}} Although the National Banknote Company ceased to issue U. S. Stamps after being supplanted by Continental in 1873, it soon began to produce stamps for Peru, on a contract that stipulated the use of the grilling process. Grills of three different types appear on regular issue stamps of Peru produced between 1874 and 1884. One of these Peru grills displays the horizontal ridges that characterize the American Z grill, but the Peruvian version is smaller in size, measuring 9 x 14 mm.{{cite web|url=http://www.1847us.com/Grills.htm|title=Grills on U. S. Stamps|publisher=1847us.com|accessdate=2014-06-24}} The other two grills measure, respectively, 11 x 15½ mm. and 10 x 12 mm. == See also == * [[Z Grill]] The Benjamin Franklin Z-Grill 1c stamp 1868. == External links == *[http://www.siegelauctions.com/enc/1867.htm Siegel Auction Galleries - 1867–68 U.S. Grilled Issues] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grill (Philately)}} [[Category:Philatelic terminology]] [[Category:Philately of the United States]]

revision.text:
The '''Grizzly Bear''' is an early 20th-century dance style. It started in San Francisco, along with the [[Bunny Hug]] and [[Texas Tommy (dance)|Texas Tommy]] and was also done on the [[Staten Island]] ferry boats in the 1900s. It has been said that dancers [[John Jarrott]] and [[Louise Gruenning]] introduced this dance as well as the [[Turkey trot (dance)|Turkey Trot]] at [[Ray Jones Café]] in Chicago, Illinois around 1909. The Grizzly Bear was first introduced to Broadway audiences in the [[Ziegfeld Follies]] of 1910 by [[Fanny Brice]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=q8qwAAAAIAAJ&q=%22grizzly+bear%22+%22fanny+brice%22&dq=%22grizzly+bear%22+%22fanny+brice%22&hl=en&ei=WPOtTM7tGcP48AaL57DvBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBTgK Popular music, 1900-1919: an annotated guide to American popular songs]</ref>
The dance was rough and clumsy. During the dance, the dancers would yell out: "It's a Bear!" The genuine Grizzly Bear step was in correct imitation of the movements of a dancing bear, moving or dancing to the side. A very heavy step to the side with a decided bending of the upper part of the body from one side to the other, a decidedly ungraceful and undignified movement when performed as a dance.
It was reported that one of the reasons former President [[Woodrow Wilson]]'s [[United States presidential inaugural balls|inaugural ball]] was cancelled was because of his "disapproval of such modern dances as the turkey trot, the grizzly bear and the bunny hug".<ref>{{cite news |title=Wilson, Fearing Guests Would Dance Grizzly Bear and Bunny Hug, Calls Off Inaugural Ball |author=Special to The Free Press |newspaper=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=January 21, 1913 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/freep/access/1749625932.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Jan+21%2C+1913&author=&pub=Detroit+Free+Press+(1858-1922)&desc=Wilson%2C+Fearing+Guests+Would+Dance+Grizzly+Bear+and+Bunny+Hug%2C+Calls+Off+Inaugural+Ball&pqatl=google |accessdate=October 7, 2010}}</ref> Not long before this, in 1912, New York placed the dance under a "social ban", along with other "huggly-wiggly dances", like the [[Turkey trot (dance)|Turkey Trot]] and the [[Boston Dip]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Grizzly-Bear Dance |author= |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] |date=March 30, 1912 |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19120330.2.96 |accessdate=October 7, 2010}}</ref> It was also condemned in numerous cities across the US during the same time period, with many considering it to be a "degenerate dance".<ref>{{cite news |title="Grizzly Bear" And "Turkey Trot" Are Doomed As Degenerate Dances, But The "Boston" Will Live, Says Terpsichorean Expert|first= |last= |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Press]] |date=January 11, 1912 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nywbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7EgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4005,2416078&dq=grizzly-bear-dance&hl=en |accessdate=October 7, 2010}}</ref>
However, a large portion of society accepted the dance, along with other similar dances. The Grizzly Bear dance was featured "on Broadway, in vaudeville, and at cabaret performances". In fact, it is believed that the first introduction to the "general public" of the dance came about in the original "Broadway production of ''Over the River''" in 1912.<ref>{{cite book |title=The wicked waltz and other scandalous dances: outrage at couple dancing in the 19th and early 20th centuries |last=Knowles |first=Mark |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2009 |publisher=McFarland |location= |isbn= |page=67 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XAzP__xv7CkC&pg=PA65&dq=%22Grizzly+Bear%22+%22dance%22&hl=en&ei=2vmtTKWALcGB8gbW6sDbBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Grizzly%20Bear&f=false |accessdate=October 7, 2010}}</ref>
In 2015, Boulder-based contemporary dance artist [[Christopher Reetz]] revitalized interest in the "Grizzly Bear". In a February 2015 interview, Reetz described his interpretation of the dance: "First, you're riding a bear. Then, you are the bear".
==In popular culture== *In the 1912 song hit ''That Shakespearian Rag'' by [[Dave Stamper]] and [[Gene Buck]], the dance is referenced in the refrain. *In episode 2, season 1, of the British television period drama [[Downton Abbey]], the footman Thomas Barrow teaches the kitchen maid Daisy how to dance the grizzly bear.<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Script Line: Transcribed Film and TV Scripts - Downton Abbey: Episode 1x02 | url = http://scriptline.livejournal.com/56158.html | publisher = | date = | accessdate = 5 February 2014 }}</ref> *One of the early Tin Pan Alley hits of the classic composer Irving Berlin was called "The Grizzley Bear." The song explains the origins of the dance and even describes how the dancers danced to this ragtime ditty. *In episode 2, in miniseries Indian Summers on PBS, the Grizzle Bear Dance is performed by some of the British expatriate population during an evening soiree. *Folk-rock group The Youngbloods released their song "Grizzly Bear" in 1966, which mentions a woman dancing the Grizzly Bear, possibly in San Francisco. * Folk singer Bill Morrissey's song, "Grizzly Bear", employs the phrase "... to dance the Grizzly Bear."
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grizzly Bear (Dance)}} [[Category:Social dance]] [[Category:Dance terminology]]

Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Hebrew edition of Wikipedia" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Hebrew edition of Wikipedia}} {{primary sources|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox website | name = {{Wiki favicon}} Hebrew Wikipedia | screenshot = Hebrew wikipedia main page 2010.png | screenshot_size = 240px | logo = Wikipedia-logo-v2-he.svg | logo_size = 150px | caption = Snapshot of Hebrew Wikipedia main page, 2010 | url = [http://he.wikipedia.org/ he.wikipedia.org] | commercial = No | location = | type = [[Internet encyclopedia project]] | language = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | registration = Optional | owner = [[Wikimedia Foundation]] | author = }} The '''Hebrew Wikipedia''' ({{lang-he|{{#property:P1448}}}}, {{IPA-he|wikiˈpedja ha(ʔ)entsikloˈpedja haχofˈʃit|IPA}}) is the [[Modern Hebrew|Hebrew language]] edition of [[Wikipedia]]. This edition was started on 11 May 2001<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lists.wikimedia.org/pipermail/wikipedia-l/2001-May/000116.html|title=Wikipedia-l new language wikis}}</ref> and contains more than {{formatnum:{{#expr:{{NUMBEROF|ARTICLES|he}} round -3}}}} [[encyclopedia article|articles]] as of {{CURRENTMONTHNAME}} {{CURRENTYEAR}}.
==About==
===Timeline history=== * '''July 8, 2003''': The Hebrew edition of Wikipedia was launched. * '''October 25, 2003''': The 1,000th article was written. * '''July 22, 2004''': The first meeting of Hebrew Wikipedians took place in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]]. * '''September 10, 2004''': The 10,000th article was written. * '''September 20, 2004''': The [[:he:דגל קזחסטן|Hebrew version]] of the [[Flag of Kazakhstan]] article became the one millionth article created in all Wikipedias. * '''December 24, 2006''': The 50,000th article was written. * '''January 10, 2010''': The 100,000th article was written. * '''August 29, 2013''': The 150,000th article was written. * '''December 28, 2016''': The 200,000th article was written.
===Features=== The Hebrew Wikipedia has several topics on which organized article writing projects were held, among them Wikitort - an academic project to write original articles about [[tort law]],<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:פרויקט WIKITORT]]</ref> PhysiWiki - a project to write and improve articles about [[Physics]] with the cooperation of [[Weizmann Institute of Science]],<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:מיזמי ויקיפדיה/פיזיוויקי]]</ref> and ongoing academic projects.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עבודות ויקידמיות]]</ref>
Another major area of work is [[Jewish history]] and the [[History of Israel]]. Such articles often include original photos taken by the writers. In 2006 the Elef Millim project<ref>[[:meta:Elef Millim project]]</ref> ({{lang-en|Thousand Words project}}) was created; its purpose is to enrich Wikipedia with free images. As a part of this project, groups of Israeli Wikipedians meet for field trips in various places in [[Israel]] in order to take pictures and bring members of the Hebrew Wikipedia community together.
[[Hebrew spelling]] is a matter of debate. The standards published by the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] are not meticulously followed in common usage, so the Hebrew Wikipedia community decides on problematic cases of spelling by discussions or polls for the sake of consistency within the project. When technically possible, spelling decisions are periodically enforced using automatic replacement by a [[Internet bot|bot]].<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:בוט/בוט החלפות]]</ref>
===Other information=== Over the years, Hebrew Wikipedia has become one of the most popular sources of information for [[Israelis]]. In a 2012 [[qualitative research]], 51 Israeli teachers of different grades were asked about their use habits of Wikipedia, and most of them responded that they don't use it as the main source for teaching, and instead search for other reliable websites on Google. Hebrew Wikipedia's requirements for [[Wikipedia:Notability|notability]] standards are relatively very strict.
Hebrew Wikipedia also conducts yearly competitions, sometimes with the assistance of the [[Wikimedia foundation]].
Hebrew Wikipedia users have turned the website into a more socially connected place. Sometimes, users meet up for a [[picnic]], or edit alongside their family members. Currently, 76% of the editors are men, and 23% are women.
===2010 Knesset meeting=== On the occasion of the 100,000 articles milestone, the Science and Technology Committee of the [[Knesset]] (Israeli parliament) invited Wikipedia contributors and users to the 2 February 2010 morning meeting, to join in a debate about Wikipedia and other [[open-source software|open-source]] resources. Some Wikipedia contributors at the meeting criticized "the lack of government cooperation with their efforts to compile a free online Hebrew-language encyclopedia," as well as sharing complaints from Wikipedia editors abroad that since the [[Israel Defense Forces]] does not release photos for [[copyleft|free redistribution]] on the Internet, the sole source of available pictures for entries such as the [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]] and the [[2006 Lebanon War]] are the [[Palestinian people|Palestinians]].<ref>{{cite news | first = | last =| authorlink =| author =Rebecca Anna Stoil| coauthors =| title =Is Wikipedia good for the Jews?| url = http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=167613| format =| work =| publisher = [[Jerusalem Post]]| location =| id =| pages =| page =| date = 2010-02-02| accessdate =| archiveurl =| archivedate =}}</ref>
===Comparisons with other language editions=== In July 2006, Hebrew Wikipedia had one of the highest amounts of bytes per article, and the highest of all editions on Wikipedia with over 20,000 articles.<ref>[http://stats.wikimedia.org/EN/TablesArticlesBytesPerArticle.htm Wikimedia Statistics Tool]</ref>
Whereas the English Wikipedia requires a general consensus for deleting articles (hence deletion discussion is not considered to be a voting process), the Hebrew Wikipedia has adopted a policy of deletion upon a 55% majority, with no minimum number of votes.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:מדיניות המחיקה|Hebrew Wikipedia deletion policy page]]</ref> In these votes, only registered users with one month seniority and at least 100 edits in the article, image, category or template namespaces in the past 90 days can vote.
====Strict inclusion criteria==== Adding on the aforementioned, comparing to English Wikipedia, Hebrew Wikipedia is much more conservative, regarding what types of content may be in it<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:מה ויקיפדיה איננה]]</ref> - even when complying with all the basic guidelines for good encyclopedic writing.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים]]</ref><ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:מדריך לכתיבת ערכים]]</ref>
The inclusion criteria are detailed under the "principles and guidelines" page.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים]]</ref> Some examples: * Articles on porn movies will be deleted unless they became cultural symbols.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים ליצירת ערכים/פורנוגרפיה]]</ref> * Articles on porn stars will be deleted unless they have other notable aspects in their lives. * A book has to meet one of these four criteria: published by a known publisher, sold 10,000 copies, won a prize, or received good reviews.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים ליצירת ערכים/ספרים]]</ref> * Writers have to write at least two books to be notable as writers.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים ליצירת ערכי אישים]]</ref> * Singers and bands have to release an album before they get an article.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים ליצירת ערכי אישים]]</ref> * Articles on student films will be deleted unless they won first prize in a film festival or were screened in mainstream cinemas.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:עקרונות וקווים מנחים ליצירת ערכים/סרטי סטודנטים]]</ref>
List articles are rare in general in Hebrew Wikipedia. In particular, lists of TV series episodes are not accepted, even as part of the articles on the series.
Other fairly controversial topics are articles of small schools and other minor educational institutions.<ref>[[:he:ויקיפדיה:גבולות/מוסדות]]</ref>
{| align=right |<gallery widths="130px" heights="120px" perrow="3"> File:5YearsHeWP02.png|Hebrew Wikipedia's logo on its 5th birthday File:Roaring Lion 2014 award to Wikimedia Israel.jpg|The ''Roaring Lion 2014'' awarded by the Israel Public Relations Associations </gallery> |}
=="Hamichlol" mirror for ultra-Orthodox== {{main|Hamichlol}}
==See also== *[[Wikimedia Israel]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{InterWiki|code=he}} * {{he icon}} [http://he.wikipedia.org Hebrew Wikipedia] * {{he icon}} [http://he.m.wikipedia.org/ Hebrew Wikipedia mobile version] * {{he icon}} [[:he:ויקיפדיה:פרסומים בתקשורת]] - a list of mass media articles covering the Hebrew Wikipedia * {{he icon}} [[:he:ויקיפדיה:פרסומים אקדמיים]] - a list of academic papers about the Hebrew Wikipedia

revision.text:
The '''Heliastic oath''' ({{lang-grc|ἡλιαστικὸς ὅρκος}}; ''heliastikos horkos'') was an [[oath]] sworn by jurors in the [[ancient Athens|ancient Athenian]] [[law court (ancient Athens)|law court]]s.
In [[Demosthenes]]' speech ''Against Timocrates'', the oath was quoted, and using quotations from other speeches, we can reconstruct the oath's main lines. The oath was sworn in the names of [[Zeus]], [[Apollo]], and [[Demeter]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/socrates/greekcrimpro.html | title=Criminal Procedure in Ancient Greece | accessdate=2013-04-30}}</ref> At the end of the oath, the juror said a curse against himself if he should break his oath. Voting in the court was secret though, so a juror could not be accused of breaking the oath. However, the juror could experience [[divine punishment]] for breaking the oath.
==Oath== "I will cast my vote in consonance with the laws and with the decrees passed by the Assembly and by the Council, but, if there is no law, in consonance with my sense of what is most just, without favour or enmity. I will vote only on the matters raised in the charge, and I will listen impartially to accusers and defenders alike." <ref>{{cite book | title=Athenian Democracy in the Age of Demosthenes | publisher=Bristol Classical Press | author=Hansen, Mogens | year=1998 | isbn=9781853995859}}</ref>
German philologist Max Fränkel (1846 - 1903) reconstructed the entire oath as follows: "I will vote according to the laws and the votes of the Demos of Athenians and the Council of the Five Hundred, and concerning matters about which there are no laws by the most just understanding, and for the sake of neither favour nor enmity. And I will vote concerning the very matters about which the prosecution is, and I will listen to both the accusers and defendants, both of them equally. I swear these things by Zeus, Apollo, and Demeter, and may I have many good things if I swear well, but destruction for me and my family if I forswear." <ref>Fränkel, Max (1877) ''Die attischen Geschworenengerichte. Ein Beitrag zum attischen Staatsrecht'', Berlin. Quoted in Mirhady, David C., "The Dikasts' Oath and the Question of Fact." Translated by Mirhady, David C.</ref>
==See also== * [[Bouleutic oath]] * [[Heliaia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Ancient Greek law]] [[Category:Athenian democracy]] [[Category:Oaths]]
{{AncientGreece-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Sir | name = (Charles) Hilary Jenkinson | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Legum Doctor|LL.D]], [[Society of Antiquaries of London|FSA]] | image = Sir Charles Hilary Jenkinson.jpg | caption = Hilary Jenkinson, 1949 |parents = William Wilberforce Jenkinson Alice Leigh Bedale | spouse = Alice Violet | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1882|11|1}} | birth_place = [[Streatham]], London, England | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1961|03|05|1882|11|01}} | death_place = London, England | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Horsham]], Sussex | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = British | other_names = | education = [[Dulwich College]] | alma_mater = [[Pembroke College, Cambridge]] | occupation = Archivist | years_active = | employer = | organization = }}
'''Sir Charles Hilary Jenkinson''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE|LLD|FSA|FRHistS}} (1 November 1882 – 5 March 1961)<ref name="ODNB">Johnson and Brodie 2008.</ref> was a British [[archivist]] and [[Archival science|archival theorist]], regarded as the figure most responsible for bringing continental European concepts of archival theory to the English-speaking world.
== Personal life == Born in [[Streatham]], London, Jenkinson was the son of William Wilberforce Jenkinson, a land agent, and Alice Leigh Bedale.<ref name="ODNB" /> He was educated at [[Dulwich College]] and [[Pembroke College, Cambridge]], graduating with first class honours in Classics in 1904.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=January 2008|title=Jenkinson, Sir (Charles) Hilary|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-34177?rskey=RgKgdn&result=1|journal=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-34177|via=}}</ref>
During the [[First World War]], he joined the [[Royal Garrison Artillery]], and served in France and [[Belgium]] from 1916 to 1918.<ref name=":3" />
Jenkinson married Alice Violet Rickards in 1910. She died in 1960. Jenkinson died a year later on 5 March 1961 at St. Thomas Hospital, London. They had no children.<ref name="ODNB" /><ref name=":3" />
==Career== In 1906, he joined the staff of the [[Public Record Office]] and worked on the arrangement and classification of the records of the medieval [[Exchequer]]. In 1912, he was put in charge of the search room, which he then reorganized according to criticisms alleged in the first report of the Royal Commission on Public Records.<ref name=":3" /> After his military service, Jenkinson worked at the [[War Office]] until 1920.<ref name="ODNB"/>
Returning to the Public Record Office, he reorganized the repairing department and later the repository, to which he moved in 1929. He was appointed secretary and principal assistant keeper in 1938.<ref name="ODNB"/>
During 1944 and 1945, he paid several extended visits to Italy, Germany, and Malta as War Office Adviser on Archives, attached to the [[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program|Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives Subcommission]], playing an important role in archives protection in those countries from the worst of the depredations of war.<ref>Bell 1962.</ref><ref>Johnson 1957, p. xxvi.</ref><ref name="Bradsher">{{cite web | url=https://text-message.blogs.archives.gov/2014/01/23/sir-hilary-jenkinson-of-the-public-record-office-an-archivist-monuments-man/ | title=Sir Hilary Jenkinson of the Public Record Office: An Archivist Monuments Man | date=23 January 2014 | accessdate=23 January 2014 | author=Bradsher, Greg}}</ref> In 1947, Jenkinson, along with H. E. Bell, advocated the protection and preservation of a country's archives, even during times of war,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cox |first=Douglas |title=National Archives and International Conflicts: The Society of American Archivists and War |journal=The American Archivist |year=2011 |volume=74 |issue=2 |pages=451–81 |jstor=23079046 }}</ref> so that the "sanctity of evidence" may be preserved in the records.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Jenkinson|first=Hilary|date=1944|title=British Archives and The War|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.7.1.k6t126j728mh8405|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=7|issue=1|pages=1–17|doi=10.17723/aarc.7.1.k6t126j728mh8405|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref>
From 1947 until his retirement in 1954, Jenkinson served as the deputy keeper (chief executive officer) of the repository at the Public Record Office.<ref name="ODNB" /> During this tenure, Jenkinson was instrumental in acquiring more facilities in [[Ashridge|Ashridge, Hertfordshire]] as further records storage, and facilities in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]] to serve as temporary housing for records in the process of being transferred to the Public Record Office.<ref name=":3" />
Jenkinson lectured on [[palaeography]], [[diplomatics|diplomatic]], and [[archives]] in Cambridge, [[King's College London]] and [[University College London]]. He wrote a number of books on palaeography and diplomatic, and his ''Manual of Archive Administration'' (1922; revised edition 1937) became a highly influential work on [[Archival science|archival practice]] in Britain and Ireland.
Jenkinson served as Honorary Secretary of the [[Surrey Archaeological Society]]. He took a leading part in establishing its daughter organization, the [[Surrey Record Society]], in 1912; and thereafter, as secretary and general editor until 1950, in establishing its principles of editing and records publication.<ref>Johnson 1957, pp. xv–xvii.</ref> He was a founder, Joint Honorary Secretary (1932–47) and Vice-President (1954–61) of the [[British Records Association]]; President of the [[Jewish Historical Society of England]] (1953–55); and President of the [[Society of Archivists]] (1955–61). He also played an important role in the setting up of the [[Royal Commission on Historical Manuscripts#National Register of Archives|National Register of Archives]] in 1945. Jenkinson served as the British representative for the UNESCO International Council on Archives, later becoming a vice-president of the Council.<ref name=":3" />
==Archival theory== Jenkinson's ''Manual of Archive Administration'' was first published in 1922, and republished in a second edition (revised and expanded, but not significantly altered in its principles) in 1937. It was reissued with a new introduction by Roger Ellis in 1965. The book is described by John Ridener as "one of the most widely recognized treatises on the theory of archives and archival work" for introducing continental archival concepts to Britain (and the English-speaking world), along with his own original interpretations.<ref>Ridener 2009, p. 41.</ref> For example, Jenkinson rejected the practice of accepting singular documents into an archive, as well as the acceptance of private papers, which he considered to be a flaw of the French and Belgian philosophies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brubaker|first=Robert|date=1966|title=Archival Principles and the Curator of Manuscripts|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.29.4.8538576776w21r71|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=29|issue=4|pages=505–514|doi=10.17723/aarc.29.4.8538576776w21r71|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref> However, Margaret Procter argues that despite Jenkinson's "iconic" status, his work also rested to a considerable degree on an existing British theoretical tradition.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Margaret |last=Procter |title=Life before Jenkinson: the development of British archival theory and thought at the turn of the twentieth century |journal=Archives |volume=33 |year=2008 |pages=140–61 }}</ref>
Key elements in Jenkinson's archival theory included the following:<ref>Discussed in Ridener 2009, pp. 41–68.</ref> *The [[Objectivity (philosophy)|objectivity]] of the archival record *[[Archival science#The principle of provenance|The principle of provenance]] *''[[Respect des fonds|Le respect pour les fonds]]'' and the significance of the inter-relatedness of records<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Hohmann|first=Paige|date=2016|title=On Impartiality and Interrelatedness: Reactions to Jenkinsonian Appraisal in the Twentieth Century|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/0360-9081.79.1.14|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=79|issue=1|pages=14–25|doi=10.17723/0360-9081.79.1.14|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref> *Organic nature of archival records in creation, preservation, and relationship with other records<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Cappon|first=Lester|date=1956|title=Historical Manuscripts as Archives: Some Definitions and Their Application|url=http://www.americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.19.2.4402r63w3t257gv8|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=19|issue=2|pages=101–110|doi=10.17723/aarc.19.2.4402r63w3t257gv8|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref> *Necessity of continual custody and control of archival records in order to retain significance<ref name=":4" /> *The archivist as impartial custodian: Jenkinson believed that [[archival appraisal]] (including the weeding-out and destruction of unimportant records) was ''not'' the responsibility of archivists, but of record creators, to be undertaken before the records were transferred to the archive.<ref name=":6" /> Jenkinson also reinforced the idea that the archivist is not an analyst of content, but a conservator of any relevant evidence for those who do wish to consult the records.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Holmes|first=Oliver|date=1961|title=Sir Hilary Jenkinson, 1882-1961|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.24.3.e521g515xp0n60u1|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=24|issue=3|pages=345–347|doi=10.17723/aarc.24.3.e521g515xp0n60u1|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref>
Jenkinson saw "the good Archivist" as "perhaps the most selfless devotee of Truth the modern world produces".<ref name=":5" /> "His Creed, the Sanctity of Evidence; his Task, the Conservation of every Scrap of Evidence attaching to the Documents committed to his charge; his Aim, to provide, without prejudice or afterthought, for all who wish to know the Means of Knowledge."<ref>Jenkinson, Hilary, "The English archivist: a new profession", in Ellis and Walne 1980, pp. 236–59 (258–9).</ref> He further reaffirmed this position by designating the archivist as being a "profession of faith," a serious professional that is uncompromising in their duty.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cline|first=Scott|date=2009|title="To the Limit of Our Integrity": Reflections on Archival Being|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.72.2.g0321510717r6j14|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=72|issue=2|pages=331–343|doi=10.17723/aarc.72.2.g0321510717r6j14|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref>
== Disputes with T. R. Schellenberg == Jenkinson had a number of theoretical differences of opinion with [[T. R. Schellenberg]], his American counterpart, particularly over the question of the archivist's role in appraisal and selection.<ref name=":0">Tschan 2002.</ref> John Ridener ascribes their differences in outlook to the fact that, in contrast to Schellenberg's concern with [[Records management|modern records management]], Jenkinson's theory was founded on "medieval record structures", and was unsuited to dealing with the increased bulk of modern records.<ref name=":2">Ridener 2009, pp. 56, 65–6.</ref> To Schellenberg, it was a matter of quality in the archives. Having an undisturbed and impartial bulk in appraisal and accession does not, in his philosophy, serve the main purpose of the modern archives: making available useful material to patrons. Some records have higher evidentiary value, while others fall short on worth, making the former more desirable for preservation. Schellenberg desired a forward-thinking practicality in the approach to archival appraisal that took into consideration the needs of future patrons (in stark contrast to Jenkinson's conservative approach), while maintaining Jenkinson's notions of record relatedness, evidentiary value, and "truth" in archival holdings.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Hohmann|first=Paige|date=2016|title=On Impartiality and Interrelatedness: Reactions to Jenkinsonian Appraisal in the Twentieth Century|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/0360-9081.79.1.14|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=79|issue=1|pages=14–25|doi=10.17723/0360-9081.79.1.14|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref>
In a private letter, Schellenberg dismissed Jenkinson as "an old fossil".<ref name=":1">Tschan 2002, pp. 176–7.</ref>
==Criticism== In his professional career at the Public Record Office, and in particular as Deputy Keeper from 1947 to 1954, he was often seen as an autocratic and inflexible conservative.<ref>Cantwell 1991, pp. 452–79, 502.</ref> Elizabeth Shepherd comments that "it was only after his retirement that the PRO could finally develop a professional archival approach to its work,"<ref>{{cite book |title=Archives and Archivists in 20th Century England |first=Elizabeth |last=Shepherd |place=Farnham |publisher=Ashgate |year=2009 |ISBN=9780754647850 |pages=81–2 }}</ref> as Jenkinson did not like individual interpretations or differing viewpoints of his philosophy.<ref name=":6" />
Jenkinson's core beliefs in the objectivity of archives and the archivist as neutral custodian have undergone considerable criticism and revision in recent years. Writing in 1997, [[Terry Cook (archivist)|Terry Cook]] commented: "At its most extreme, Jenkinson's approach would allow the archival legacy to be perverted by administrative whim or state ideology, as in the former [[Soviet Union]], where provenance was undermined by the establishment of one state [[fonds]] and archival records attained value solely by the degree to which they reflected the 'official' view of history."<ref>{{cite journal |first=Terry |last=Cook |authorlink=Terry Cook (archivist) |title=What is past is prologue: a history of archival ideas since 1898, and the future paradigm shift |journal=Archivaria |volume=43 |year=1997 |pages=17–63 (24) }}</ref>
==Honours== Jenkinson was appointed [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] in 1943 and knighted in 1949.<ref name="ODNB"/> As well as being a member of the Society of Archivists of Great Britain, Jenkinson was also an honorary member of the Society of American Archivists.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Holmes|first=Oliver|date=1961|title=Sir Hilary Jenkinson, 1882-1961|url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/pdf/10.17723/aarc.24.3.e521g515xp0n60u1|journal=The American Archivist|language=en-US|volume=24|issue=3|pages=345–347|doi=10.17723/aarc.24.3.e521g515xp0n60u1|issn=0360-9081|via=}}</ref> Jenkinson was further bestowed an honorary fellowship at [[University College London|University College, London]], as well as an honorary [[Legum Doctor|LLD]] of Aberdeen.<ref name=":3" />
==Legacy== Writing in 1980, Roger Ellis and Peter Walne commented that "[n]o one man had more influence on the establishment of the profession of archivist in Great Britain than Sir Hilary Jenkinson".<ref>Ellis and Walne 1980, p. 9.</ref> [[Terry Eastwood]] in 2003 called Jenkinson "one of the most influential archivists in the English-speaking world".<ref>Eastwood 2003, p. vii.</ref>
Jenkinson influenced the [[University of London]]'s decision to establish an archives diploma program, and would later present its first lecture.<ref name="ODNB" /> Such a program provided advancement towards Jenkinson's desire for the scientific archival profession to advance beyond his Public Records Office, and to train a new generation of archivists in his English method.<ref name=":5" /> After his death, Oliver W. Holmes wrote in the ''[[American Archivist]]'' that Jenkinson's work had become a reference source for all inexperienced staff.<ref>Holmes 1961.</ref> Since 2007, the Department of Information Studies at [[University College London]] has hosted an annual Jenkinson Lecture named in honour of Sir Hilary. The series was established to mark the sixtieth anniversary of archival education at UCL.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/dis/icarus/culture/JenkinsonLecture |title=Jenkinson Lectures |publisher=ICARUS – International Centre for Archives and Records Management Research, UCL |accessdate=3 May 2015 }}</ref>
==Principal publications== *[[iarchive:englishcourthand01john/page/n5|''English Court Hand, A.D. 1066 to 1500'', with Charles Johnson (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1915)]] *[[iarchive:palaeographyprac00jenk/page/n7|''Palaeography and the Practical Study of Court Hand'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1915)]] *''A Manual of Archive Administration'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1922; revised editions 1937 and 1965) **[[iarchive:manualofarchivea00jenk/page/n5|1922 edition via the Internet Archive]] **[[iarchive:manualofarchivea00iljenk|1937 edition via the Internet Archive]] *''Elizabethan Handwritings: a preliminary sketch'' (London: Oxford University Press/Bibliographical Society, 1922) *''The Later Court Hands in England from the Fifteenth to the Seventeenth Century'', 2 vols (1927) *''The English Archivist: a new profession'' (London: H. K. Lewis, 1948) *''A Guide to Seals in the Public Record Office'' (London: HMSO, 1954; second edition 1968) *''Selected Writings of Sir Hilary Jenkinson'', ed. Roger H. Ellis & Peter Walne (Gloucester: Alan Sutton, 1980; reissue (with a new introduction) 2003)
A fuller bibliography of Jenkinson's writings to 1956 appears as: *{{cite book| first1=Roger |last1=Ellis |first2=William |last2=Kellaway |year=1957 |chapter=A Bibliography of the Writings of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |editor-first=J. Conway |editor-last=Davies |editor-link=James Conway Davies |title=Studies presented to Sir Hilary Jenkinson, C.B.E., LL.D, F.S.A. |place=London |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=480–94 }}
'''[[Festschrift]]s''' *{{cite book |title=Studies presented to Sir Hilary Jenkinson, C.B.E., LL.D, F.S.A. |editor-first=J. Conway |editor-last=Davies |editor-link=James Conway Davies |location=London |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1957 }} *{{cite book |title=Essays in Memory of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |editor-first=Albert E. J. |editor-last=Hollaender |location=Chichester |publisher=Society of Archivists |year=1962 }}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book| last=Bell |first=H. E. |year=1962 |chapter=Archivist itinerant: Jenkinson in wartime Italy |editor-first=Albert E. J. |editor1-last=Hollaender |title=Essays in Memory of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |place=Chichester |publisher=Society of Archivists |pages=167–77 }} *{{cite book |last1=Bell |first1=H. E. |first2=Hilary |last2=Jenkinson |title=Italian Archives During the War and at Its Close |series=British Committee on the Preservation and Restitution of Works of Art, Archives and Other Material in Enemy Hands |place=London |publisher=HMSO |year=1947 }} *{{cite book |first=John D. |last=Cantwell |title=The Public Record Office, 1838–1958 |publisher=HMSO |place=London |year=1991 |ISBN=0114402248 |pages=397–507 }} *{{cite book| last=Eastwood |first=Terence M. |authorlink=Terry Eastwood |year=2003 |chapter=Introduction to the 2003 reissue |editor1-first=Roger H. |editor1-last=Ellis |editor2-first=Peter |editor2-last=Walne |title=Selected Writings of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |place=Chicago |publisher=The Society of American Archivists |ISBN=1-931666-03-2 |pages=vii–xx }} *{{cite journal |last=Ellis |first=Roger H. |title=Recollections of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |journal=Journal of the Society of Archivists |volume=4 |year=1971 |pages=261–75 |doi=10.1080/00379817109513966}} *{{cite book| year=1980 |editor1-first=Roger H. |editor1-last=Ellis |editor2-first=Peter |editor2-last=Walne |title=Selected Writings of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |place=Stroud |publisher=Alan Sutton |ISBN=0-904387-52-6 }} *{{cite journal |last=Holmes |first=Oliver W. |title=Sir Hilary Jenkinson, 1882–1961 |journal=The American Archivist |volume=24 |issue=3 |year=1961 |pages=345–7 |jstor=40290906 }} *{{cite book| last=[Johnson |first=H. C.] |year=1957 |chapter=Memoir of Sir Hilary Jenkinson |editor-first=J. Conway |editor-last=Davies |editor-link=James Conway Davies |title=Studies presented to Sir Hilary Jenkinson, C.B.E., LL.D, F.S.A. |place=London |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=xiii–xxx }} *{{ODNBweb |first1=H. C. |last1=Johnson |first2=Marc (reviser) |last2=Brodie |title=Jenkinson, Sir (Charles) Hilary (1882–1961) |origyear=2004 |edition=online |year=2008 |id=34177 }} *{{cite book |first=John |last=Ridener |title=From Polders to Postmodernism: a concise history of archival theory |publisher=Litwin Books |place=Duluth, Minnesota |year=2009 |pages=41–68 }} *{{cite journal |first=Reto |last=Tschan |title=A comparison of Jenkinson and Schellenberg on appraisal |journal=The American Archivist |volume=65 |issue=2 |year=2002 |pages=176–195 |url=http://americanarchivist.org/doi/abs/10.17723/aarc.65.2.920w65g3217706l1 }}

page.title: Historical Dictionary Project of the Hebrew Language

revision.text:
{{outdated|date=May 2014}} The '''Historical Dictionary Project''' of the Hebrew Language (HDP) (Hebrew: מִפְעַל הַמִּלּוֹן הַהִיסְטוֹרִי) is a long-term research undertaking of the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]]. According to the Academy's website, "The overarching goal of the HDP is to present the history and development of the Hebrew lexicon, from the earliest occurrences of words down through their most recent documentation."<ref>Historical Dictionary Project, Academy of the Hebrew Language. [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/English/HistoricalDictionaryProject/Pages/default.aspx] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> It aims to encompass the entire Hebrew lexicon throughout its history; that is, to present every Hebrew word in its morphological, semantical, and contextual development from its first appearance in written texts to the present.<ref>Guide to the Hebrew Language Historical Dictionary Project, Indiana University. [http://www.indiana.edu/~letrs/help-services/QuickGuides/Maagarim/maagarim.html] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref>
The editorial board consists of Prof. Chaim A. Cohen, editor-in-chief;<ref>Israeli scholars set out to compile the ultimate Hebrew dictionary, Ha'aretz [http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/israeli-scholars-set-out-to-compile-the-ultimate-hebrew-dictionary-1.423490] Retrieved 2012-07-12</ref> Prof. Steven (Shmuel) Fassberg, associate editor;<ref>Hebrew University of Jerusalem. [http://pluto.huji.ac.il/~fassberg/] Retrieved 2012-07-27.</ref> and Dr. Gabriel Birnbaum, writer of the entries.<ref>Academy of the Hebrew Language, dictionary personnel. Retrieved 2012-07-02. [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/al_haakademya/pages/tafkidim.aspx]</ref>
== Origins ==
As early as 1937, the president of Va'ad HaLashon ("The Language Committee", which later became the Academy of the Hebrew Language), Prof. [[Naftali Herz Tur-Sinai]],<ref>Jewish Virtual Library. [http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0020_0_20116.html] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> proposed the establishment of "a large endeavor which prepares an academic dictionary of our language, in all of the periods and evolutions that it has endured from the moment it is documented, until today." A formal decision to undertake the HDP was taken in 1955.<ref>Proceedings of the Academy of the Hebrew Language, Volume One, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=z_vuT9PQD8fV4QTo0rjbDQ&id=uSc_AQAAIAAJ&dq=%22%D7%96%D7%99%D7%9B%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%95%D7%AA+%D7%94%D7%90%D7%A7%D7%93%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%94+%D7%9C%D7%9C%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F+%D7%94%D7%A2%D7%91%D7%A8%D7%99%D7%AA+%D7%9B%D7%A8%D7%25 Page 45] (Hebrew). Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref>
== Preparation ==
The HDP is based on Hebrew texts up until 1100 CE, and large selections of Hebrew literature from the period thereafter until the founding of the [[State of Israel]]. As much scholarly attention had already been given to the [[Hebrew Bible]] and the [[Pseudepigrapha]], it was decided to begin with texts from the post-biblical period. The database thus reflects more than 2000 years of Hebrew writing. Such a project requires a large textual database, and the HDP was one of the first in the world to develop and use a computerized concordance. In 2005, some fifty years after commencement, it was decided there was enough material to begin the writing of entries.<ref>Historical Dictionary Project, Academy of the Hebrew Language. [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/English/HistoricalDictionaryProject/Pages/default.aspx] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref>
== Sources ==
The Academy initially debated as to whether it should create a series of dictionaries according to periods or literary genres, or whether it should work towards a single integrated work. In 1959 it was decided that there would be one central dictionary containing all periods, i.e., ancient, medieval and modern Hebrew literature.<ref>Academy of the Hebrew Language, types of literature [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/English/HistoricalDictionaryProject/Types%20of%20Literature/Pages/default.aspx] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> Material was first gathered from ancient literature written between 200 BCE and 1100 CE, and later, [[Hebrew_literature#Modern_Hebrew_literature|modern literature]] from 1750 onwards. Sources include material discovered at the [[Cairo Genizah]]. Material from [[Karaite Judaism|Karaite]] sources is also included, and material from [[Samaritan]] sources may be added in the future. Compilation of the list of documentary sources for the dictionary was completed in 1963 with the publication of ''Sefer ha-Meqorot [Source Book]'' for sources "from the canonization of the Bible until the conclusion of the [[Geonic]] period."<ref>Kernerman Dictionaries [http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7.html] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> The ''Source Book'' serves as the foundation for all work on the dictionary.
== Database ==
Work on the HDP is based on the best available manuscripts of the texts, which are entered into the database and then analyzed. In those cases where there are several extant manuscripts, the clearest and most complete manuscript is selected for incorporation into the dictionary.
In 1982 the Academy published a sample entry for the dictionary based on the triliteral root ערב. The 88-page entry was published in the Academy’s journal "Leshonenu" ("Our Language").<ref>Leshonenu [https://books.google.com/books?ei=cQPvT_O1Hon44QThoeD6DQ&id=HgRctbcx3BAC&dq=%D7%9C%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%A0%D7%95+%D7%9E%D7%95+%28%D7%AA%D7%A9%D7%9E%22%D7%91%29%2C+%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91%D7%A8%D7%AA+4-3&q=%D7%A2%D7%A8%D7%91#search_anchor 41] (Hebrew). Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref>
In 2010, the database of Hebrew texts from the post-biblical period down through the 11th century, and the database of modern texts from 1750 onwards, were united into a single database. This database serves as an archive of not only individual words, but also complete texts that have been carefully copied from their source. In addition to enabling grammatical analyses and concordance searches, the archives also contain unique corpora, such as Hebrew poetry from the 11th century. The database is accessible to the public.<ref>Database [http://hebrew-treasures.huji.ac.il/] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref>
The database draws upon some 4,300 Hebrew sources, from the classic [[Rabbinic literature]] period (2nd century BCE) through the [[Geonic period]] (11th century CE) to 1947. Literary strata and genres represented include the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]], inscriptions, [[Talmud]] and [[Midrash]], Geonic literature, [[prayer]] and [[piyyut]], Karaite literature, science, deeds, colophons, amulets, and the like. Essentially a concordance, the online resource accesses all the words in the database and enables retrieval of citations according to roots, lemmata, and declined forms or combinations, as well as of specific texts by title, author, date, or literary genre.<ref>Humanities and Social Sciences Net Online [http://www.h-net.org/announce/show.cgi?ID=153256] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> It is updated as new research becomes available and as more old texts are discovered.
As of 7 June 2010, the twenty-million word database contained 4,056 Hebrew roots. Of its 54,807 entries, 14,592 are nouns, adjectives and adverbs, and 13,979 are verbs. The balance consists of personal names, numbers, prepositions and similar lexical items. The size of the database on that date was about 40 gigabytes.<ref>Akadem [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/hadash/Documents/%D7%90%D7%A7%D7%93%D7%9D%20-%20%D7%9B%D7%9C%20%D7%94%D7%92%D7%99%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%95%D7%AA/akad41.pdf 41] Retrieved 2012-07-02.</ref> The complete lexical archive will contain at least 25 million quotations.<ref>Literary and Linguistic Computing, Oxford Journals. Retrieved 2012-07-02. [http://llc.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/4/271.extract]</ref>
== External links == * [http://en.hebrew-academy.org.il/historical-dictionary-project/ Historical Dictionary Project] at the Academy of the Hebrew Language.
Three samples of the entry for the triliteral root ערב [http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav174.gif a]<ref>[http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav174.gif Kernerman Dictionaries. Retrieved 2012-07-02]</ref> [http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav201.gif b]<ref>[http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav201.gif Kernerman Dictionaries. Retrieved 2012-07-02]</ref> [http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav247.gif c]<ref>[http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7arav247.gif Kernerman Dictionaries. Retrieved 2012-07-02]</ref> * [http://llc.oxfordjournals.org/content/4/4/271.extract The Historical Dictionary of the Hebrew Language], Literary & Linguistic Computing, Vol. 4, Issue 4, 1989, Pages 271-273. Retrieved 2012-07-02. * [http://kdictionaries.com/kdn/kdn12-3-7.html The Historical Dictionary of the Hebrew Language], Kernerman Dictionary News, Number 12, July 2004. * [http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0001_0_00344.html Academy of the Hebrew Language] at Jewish Virtual Library. * [http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/israeli-scholars-set-out-to-compile-the-ultimate-hebrew-dictionary-1.423490 Israeli scholars set out to compile the ultimate Hebrew dictionary], Ha’aretz, April 10, 2012. Retrieved 2012-07-02.
== References ==

[[File:Portrait of Joseph Harris, 'Gomer' (4670840).jpg|thumb|Portrait of Joseph Harris, 'Gomer' c.1860]] '''Joseph Harris''' (1773 – 10 August 1825) was a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[Baptist]] minister, author, and journal editor. A [[Welsh language]] poet, he took the Biblical name of '''[[Gomer (Bible)|Gomer]]''' as his [[bardic name]]. On 1 January 1814 he launched the first Welsh-language weekly ''[[Seren Gomer]]'' ("Star of Gomer") in [[Swansea]].
Gomer was born on a farm in [[Wolf's Castle]], [[Pembrokeshire]], where a plaque was unveiled in his memory, making the 200th anniversary of the launch of ''Seren Gomer''.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-26993436 BBC News, "Plaque unveiled for 200th anniversary of Seren Gomer". 12 April 2014]. Accessed 23 February 2016</ref> Gomer himself became a preacher during the religious revival of 1795. He married Martha Symons, and took on{{clarify|date=September 2014}} Back Street chapel. One of his best-known works, ''Cofiant Ieuan Ddu'', was a biography of his son, [[John Ryland Harris]], who worked as a typesetter for his father's printing press and died at the age of twenty.
The name of the [[Gomer Press]] was almost certainly chosen because of its founder J.D. Lewis' high regard for Joseph Harris.<ref>[http://www.gomerprinting.co.uk/history/] History of Gomer Press</ref>
==Works== *''Casgliad o Hymnau'' (1796) *''Yr Anghyffelyb Broffeswr'' (1802) *''Bwyall Grist yng Nghoed Anghrist'' (1804) *''Traethawd ar Briodol Dduwdod ein Harglwydd Iesu Grist'' (1816–17) *''Cofiant Ieuan Ddu''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *[http://wbo.llgc.org.uk/en/s-HARR-JOS-1773.html?query=joseph+harris&field=name Welsh Biography Online]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Kodi Kushalappa Gowda | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1931|05|30}} | image = | |birth_place = [[Mercara]], [[Coorg]] | spouse = | living = yes | alma_mater = [[University of Madras]],
[[Annamalai University]]| residence = | occupation = Kannada scholar, grammarian, linguist | influences = }} '''Kodi Kushalappa Gowda''' (born 30 May 1931) is a [[Kannada language|Kannada]] scholar, writer, [[Dravidologist]] and [[linguist]]. He has published over 12 books on linguistics in Kannada and English. == Early life and education == Born in 1931 at [[Kodi, Kodagu|Kodi]] village near [[Mercara]], [[Coorg Province]], Gowda graduated in Kannada from the [[University of Madras]] in 1955 and obtained his master's from the same university in 1956. He obtained his doctorate from [[Annamalai University]] in 1963. == Career == Gowda taught Kannada at the Annamalai University for 18 years and Madras University for 15 years. He has published more than 50 research papers and articles. Gowda was honoured with the Sahitya Academy Award for Kannada in 1987, Karnataka Rajyotsava award, Thimmappayya award and Nirpage award.{{cite news|title=Bantwal Kannada scholar Dr K Kushalappa Gowda bags 'Nirpage Award'|url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=91194}}{{cite news|title=Thimappayya award for Kushalappa Gowda|date=2 March 2005|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2005/03/02/stories/2005030212700300.htm|work=The Hindu}} Gowda headed the University of Madras' Kannada department till 1991. == Works == * {{cite book|title=Gowda Kannada|first=K. Kushalappa|last=Gowda|year=1970|publisher=Annamalai University}} * {{cite book|title=A Grammar of Kannada: Based on the Inscriptions of Coorg, South Kanara and North Kanara Dts.100 to 1400 A.D.|first=K. Kushalappa|last=Gowda|year=1972|publisher=Annamalai University}} * {{cite book|title=Dravidian case system|first=K. Kushalappa|last=Gowda|year=1976|publisher=Annamalai University}} * {{cite book|title=A course in modern Kannada|first=K. Kushalappa|last=Gowda|year=1991|publisher=University of Madras}} == Notes == {{reflist|2}} == References == * {{cite web|title=Department of Kannada|publisher=University of Madras|url=http://www.unom.ac.in/index.php?route=department/department/about&deptid=43}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gowda, K. Kushalappa}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century Indian linguists]] [[Category:University of Madras faculty]] [[Category:People from Kodagu district]] [[Category:Annamalai University alumni]] [[Category:Annamalai University faculty]] [[Category:University of Madras alumni]] [[Category:Kannada-language writers]] [[Category:Scholars from Karnataka]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Miri language (disambiguation){{!}}Miri language}} {{Infobox language |name=Kadugli |nativename=Central Kadu |states=[[Sudan]] |region=[[Kordofan]] |ethnicity=[[Kadugli people|Kadugli]], [[Katcha people|Katcha]], [[Damba people|Damba]], [[Tumma people|Tumma]] |speakers=75,000 |date=2004 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Nilo-Saharan |fam1=[[Kadu languages|Kadu]] |fam2=Central |dia1=Kadugli–Damba |dia2=Katcha |dia3=Miri |iso3=xtc |glotto=katc1249 |glottorefname=Katcha-Kadugli-Miri }} '''Kadugli''', also '''Katcha-Kadugli-Miri''' or '''Central Kadu''', is a [[Kadu languages|Kadu language]] or [[dialect cluster]] spoken in [[Kordofan]]. Stevenson treats the varieties as dialects of one language, and they share a single ISO code, though Schadeberg (1989) treats them as separate languages.
There are five commonly cited varieties. Three of them are rather divergent, on the verge of being distinct languages: *Katcha ''(Tolubi, Dholubi)'' *Kadugli proper ''(Dakalla, Talla, Dhalla, Toma Ma Dalla, Kudugli, Morta)'' *Miri However, they share a single orthography and use the same literacy materials (''Ethnologue'').
Of the two other commonly cited varieties, ''Damba'' is somewhat closer to Kadugli, while ''Tumma'' appears to be a (sub)dialect of Katcha.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120716194646/http://lucy.ukc.ac.uk/pub/alda/sudan/KATCHA~1.DOC Katcha-English Dictionary] (one of the [[Kadu languages]]) *[http://starling.rinet.ru/cgi-bin/response.cgi?root=new100&morpho=0&basename=new100\kad\kad&first=2&limit=-1 Katcha, Kadugli, and Miri basic lexicon at the Global Lexicostatistical Database]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Languages of Sudan}} {{Kordofanian languages}} [[Category:Languages of Sudan]] [[Category:Kadu languages]]
